stance_1: I buy meat because it is easy to store
stance_2: I eat meat five to six days a week
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that the practicality and storability of meat is a main reason they eat it frequently.

stance_1: I buy meat because it is easy to store
stance_2: I have limited storage for fresh vegetables
justification: The interviewee explicitly links limited storage for fresh vegetables to choosing meat, which is easier to store.

stance_1: I buy meat because it is easy to store
stance_2: I have transportation challenges for grocery shopping
justification: The interviewee mentions transportation difficulties as a reason for infrequent shopping, reinforcing the need for easily stored foods like meat.

stance_1: I buy meat because it is easy to store
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: The convenience of storing meat makes it harder to implement the desire to try more plant-based recipes, which often require fresher ingredients.

stance_1: I eat meat five to six days a week
stance_2: I have environmental concerns about eating meat
justification: Eating meat frequently is in tension with the interviewee’s environmental concerns, which motivate reducing meat consumption.

stance_1: I eat meat five to six days a week
stance_2: I have health concerns about eating meat
justification: The interviewee states a desire to eat less meat for health reasons, conflicting with current high consumption.

stance_1: I eat meat five to six days a week
stance_2: I feel better when I eat less meat
justification: The interviewee feels better eating less meat, which conflicts with their frequent meat consumption.

stance_1: I eat meat five to six days a week
stance_2: I have already cut out most beef
justification: Cutting out most beef suggests some reduction, but overall high meat consumption remains, showing partial conflict.

stance_1: I have environmental concerns about eating meat
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: Environmental concerns are a stated motivation for wanting to try more plant-based recipes.

stance_1: I have environmental concerns about eating meat
stance_2: I have already cut out most beef
justification: Environmental concerns support the reduction of beef consumption, as beef is often seen as environmentally impactful.

stance_1: I have health concerns about eating meat
stance_2: I feel better when I eat less meat
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that health concerns and feeling better when eating less meat are linked.

stance_1: I have health concerns about eating meat
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: Health concerns motivate the desire to try more plant-based recipes.

stance_1: I have health concerns about eating meat
stance_2: I have already cut out most beef
justification: Health concerns are a reason for reducing meat, including cutting out most beef.

stance_1: I have limited storage for fresh vegetables
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that limited storage for fresh vegetables makes it difficult to implement plant-based meals.

stance_1: I have limited storage for fresh vegetables
stance_2: I have transportation challenges for grocery shopping
justification: Both are practical limitations that together restrict the ability to buy and store fresh, plant-based foods.

stance_1: I have transportation challenges for grocery shopping
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: Transportation issues limit grocery trips, making it harder to buy fresh ingredients needed for plant-based meals.

stance_1: I have already cut out most beef
stance_2: I want to try more plant-based recipes
justification: Cutting out beef is a step towards more plant-based eating, supporting the desire to try more plant-based recipes.
